ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, I recently installed a bigbluebutton server following the instructions here http://docs.bigbluebutton.org/install/install.html I created an activity in a course allowed all enrolled users to view the session and myself as a moderator. When I click the link to the new bbb classroom I get a page that says: "You are not in a role allowed to join this session.  Would you like to log in now with a full user account?" I
can't find any info about this error anywhere.  Also, I did install the
demo api on the bbb server and I am able to create a new class room
right from the web UI of that server.  And my moodle server has full
access to the bbb server with no firewall restrictions.  Also, I copied
the url and salt from bbb-conf --secret to the plugin config in moodle
and restarted both servers just for good measure. My account is a full admin in moodle and I tried adding it to every role in the course with no luck.  I also tried several other accounts that were in the manager and student roles of the Moodle Course and gave those roles moderator under the participants section. Nothing seems to work. Is there some setting in moodle that I completely missed? Any help would be appreciated. Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BigBlueButton not able to join session
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jason, There may be a problem with the capabilities assigned to the roles you are using. Specilaly if you are not using the Moodle default admin account but a custom one. Check the capabilities you have for each role. Administrators/Site Administrators/Users/Permissions/Define roles/ [Role you need to check] Lookup for BigBlueButtonBN, there are 4 capabilities. Join is the one now used for allowing users to enter in a session. It should be activated for all roles. Let us know if that works JF

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: new VideoConferencing Plugin(s) for OpenMeetings 0.5.1
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Sebastian, Could you tell me which are the installation steps?. I've been reading this information about OpenMeetings Installation but I've got some doubts: 1.- My Moodle is installed in a remote server (Linux Machine) so I suppose that the database is listening and allowing TCP/IP connections. 2.- Open Office service must be installed on the remote server too? 3.- Do I have to install ImageMagick, gosthScript, SWFTools on the reomote server too? 4.- After doing all these steps, How could I try Openmeetings on my remote server? 5.- Finally, Do I have to install Moodle plugins by putting the folders into Moodle /mods directory? Thanks a lot for helping me!!. Cheers. Susana. Requirements full-list ) It is recommended to make/use an empty database/scheme Database available ( MySQL , Postgres ,... MSSQL , Oracle ,DB2 see Database MUST listen and allow TCP/IP connections! And the default character-set/scheme must be UTF8! For example a fresh My SQL does not listen on TCP/IP by default and has not utf8 as default-character-set defined. You have to change these settings and restart your database server so that changes take effect (mysql-config is in my.cnf). Postgres for example does also not listen by default on TCP/IP but uses by default UTF8 (since postgres 7 or 8). To change Postgres listening on TCP/IP check postgresql .conf and add your host to the pg_hba.conf. In Postgres you need to create a database using template1 cause template1 create automatically a scheme called public which is needed (and since postgres 8 you can use several schemes inside one database public is the default one Postgres-Docs ). OpenOffice-Service started and listening on port 8100 (see OpenOfficeConverter , this is not necessary for installation but for running later on) Installed ImageMagick (this is not necessary for installation but for running later on), you can get more information on http://www.imagemagick.org regarding installation. The instructions for installation can be found there http://www.imagemagick.org/script/binary-releases.php , however on most linux systems you can get it via your favorite package managers (apt-get it) Installed GhostScript (this is not necessary for installation but for running later on), you can get more information on http://pages.cs.wisc.edu/~ghost/ regarding installation. The instructions for installation can be found there, however on most linux systems you can get it via your favorite package managers (apt-get it). Installed SWFTools (this is not necessary for installation but for running later on), you can get more information on http://www.swftools.org/ regarding installation. Some of the Linux distributions already have it in there package manager see http://packages.debian.org/unstable/utils/swftools ) MAC OSx / Linux Users => Get Flash Player 10 Beta!! It fixes the CPU Problem for Streaming Video => http://labs.adobe.com/technologies/flashplayer10/

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: new VideoConferencing Plugin(s) for OpenMeetings 0.5.1
ResponsesInList.Text: *1.- My Moodle is installed in a remote server (Linux Machine) so I suppose that the database is listening and allowing TCP/IP connections.* => no, you should check that, for example PHP can use the UNIX /Socket to communicate to the database, and by default for example MySQL does not listen on TCP/IP connections. *2.- Open Office service must be installed on the remote server too?3.- Do I have to install ImageMagick, gosthScript, SWFTools on the reomote server too?* => To use all features of OpenMeetings you need OpenOffice running as a Service on your remote Server, and ImageMagick/SWFTools/Ghostscript installed on your remote Server, your probably should contact your network administrator if you never have done that before. *4.- After doing all these steps, How could I try Openmeetings on my remote server?* => You can check and use OpenMeetings like in standalone modus of OpenMeetings. Just follow the Installation Guide and it will lead you to the login Page. *5.- Finally, Do I have to install Moodle plugins by putting the folders into Moodle /mods directory?* => yes you need to install the Moodle Modules liek any other Moodle Plugin. sebastian

ResponsesInList.Title: BigBlueButton vs OpenMeetings
ResponsesInList.Text: Good Morning, I am currently investigating the use of Web Conferencing through Moodle for our distance learning courses and would like to ask the opinions of the community on which plugin would best suit our purposes. What we are looking for is something which can be used for both one to one and group web / video conferencing.  We would also require the meeting to be recorded and chat logs kept.   We are currently in the process of moving to Moodle 2.4 so that is the version we would be using this plugin for. I have looked at both and am impressed by BigBlueButtons recording capabilitites but have recently seen OpenMeetings mentioned quite a bit on the Forums so I suppose what I am looking for is a comparasion of the two and some opinions of people who currenty use either plugin. Many Thanks,

ResponsesInList.Title: Ynt: BigBlueButton vs OpenMeetings
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, having used both bigbluebutton (bbb)0.81-beta and open meetings(om) version 2.0 in real time online courses I think I have some experiences on both of them. First of all, afaik, om has plugin only for 2.2 verion of moodle; correct me if I'm wrong. The moodle plugin of om for 2.2 version migth work in moodle 2.4, but I haven't tried it personally. Finally, the followings and comments might contain some invalid information especially due to the versions of the both video conferencing tools and my personal lack of knowledge. So please feel free to correct the areas you see any incorrect information. You can give a trial shot for bbb here and om here . Anyway, here are the areas I'll compare them: 1- Chat module: In bbb chat module is vertically placed on the right by defaults, which give you the opportunity to view nearly all the messages from the participants. In om, however, it is placed horizontally in a rectangular box just beneath the whiteboard in which you can see the very few messages from the participants even if you hide the admin panel Prior to 0.81 version, bbb was showing certain characters of the participants' names (such as Grah.. instead of full name Graham Stone). But in 0.81 beta version this was corrected and full name of the participants can be seen. Again prior to 0.81 version of bbb, you could change the font color of your messages. This was a very good feature especially in discriminating the messages. However, in 0.81 version you have only one color: black. I believe this will be corrected since 0.81 version is still in beta In bbb there is also a private message area in which you can send private messages to the users similar to adobe connect. I say similar because in adobe connect the teacher is informed if a participant sends a private message to the other. In bbb, teacher is not informed if any of the users are privately chatting unless the recipient is the teacher himself. In om, afaik there is not a private chat feature available. 2- Users block: In om, users are given more permissions such as turning on their mic even if you disable them to avoid echo. bbb is more aggressive than om in this aspect: Once the moderator logs in and set turn off all mics, every new comer enters the conference as their mics off. This is a good feature to avoid echo since every user does not use a headset with mic. And in om, if you choose webinar as conference type, the mics can be bulk turned off. But this time, if you want to allow a participant to speak, you have to first click on the user's name then click again to turn on his/her mic, which requires a double click to turn on and double click to turn off. This might cause problems if you have a crowded class. 3- Tools: The tools in om is undoubtedly richer than the ones in bbb; especially the icons and type tool. In bbb 0.81 beta version type tool is added, through which you can type on the whiteboard. However, the typed items cannot be dragged to another place as it can be done in om. In om you have one useful too, which is polls, through which you can create polls (let's say questions) and ask the participants to make their choices when they are ready. At the end of the voting session a pie chart is shown. 4- Uploaded materials: The materials uploaded by the teacher in om remains in teacher's account even if s/he logs out the conference and backs to moodle. In bbb, however, once the teacher logs out and logs in again, s/he has to upload the materials again to use them. In om, you can have more than one whiteboards whereas is in bbb you can use only one whiteboard. 5- Recording: In om, you can record the session with the editing tools. I mean if you draw something on the whiteboard, it is recorded as well. However, in bbb the things that you draw on the whiteboard is not shown in the recording; only the slides and the voice of the teacher. I think this is because of the format of the recording. The slides are saved as .swf files and audio as .vaw. And they are saved separately. Another point to consider is if you have sessions one after another, you should think about the recording process one more time. I mean while the recording of the older session takes place, another live session will tried to be handled by the server : How a powerful server you have, you should think about the server load. In om, you can also define which areas of the screen to record. By this way you can record let's say the video view of the teacher. In bbb, however, only the whiteboard and chat module is recorded. As a solution, you can think about using a screen capture program. Besides commercial ones if you have a Ubuntu machine you should give a try to kazaam , which gives very good quality output with a small file size. 6- Installation: You can install both moodle and om on the same server since om runs on port 5080 while moodle runs on port 80. But personally I do not recommend running the lms and video conferencing tool on the same server, especially for production sites with large amount of participants. But if you have a small number of participants and budget, this can be considered. Although there are some attempts to run bbb on a different port apart from 80, (personally I tried it too) it stopped working after a successful 30 seconds runtime. BBB developer Fred Dixon is very decisive on this matter; bbb requires a dedicated server and has to be run on port 80 (see here ). From a technical aspect, from the outputs of our bbb server, I can say that bbb heavily relies on the processor rather than RAM of the server. You can install bbb on a Ubuntu 10.04 server easily, and you might have problems if you want to install it on a 12.04 Ubuntu server. See here for installation instructions. You can install om on Ubuntu 12.04 and even on Ubuntu 12.10 server. See here for installation instructions 7- Layout: bbb 0.81 beta version is added a new feature through which you can change the layout automatically with one click. The options are video chat, meeting, webinar, lecture assistant and lecture. You can use om more than a web conferencing tool. I mean you can create different sessions, calendar events, user account assignments through the om portal itself. In bbb, you do not have much choice but just using video conferencing features. Conclusion: Since we have been using moodle 2.5 and horizontal chat module is extremely important for us (we are using it in a language course and we frequently ask participants to share their replies/comments with us) we went back to using bbb. One more thing to add is that, personally I think, the speed of these videoconferencing tools mostly depends on the bandwidth of the server and the participants' rather than the architecture on which they are built. Best regards www.mesutaydemir.net

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ynt: BigBlueButton vs OpenMeetings
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mesut, Thanks for your review!  A few points >  However, in 0.81 version you have only one color: black. I believe this will be corrected since 0.81 version is still in beta Our goal for 0.81 was to add more features, but at the same time simplify the interface. We noticed that the welcome message in the chat was getting lost, so we assigned it the color blue to make it stand out.  To simplify the UI for the chat, we removed the ability for the user to send out messages in different colors (we were almost sure no one would notice that we removed it . > However, the typed items cannot be dragged to another place That's correct.  We'll add the ability to drag around whiteboard items in a future release. > However, in bbb the things that you draw on the whiteboard is not shown in the recording In version 0.81-beta-2 (which is getting close to a final release), BigBlueButton records all activity in the presentation area, webcams, audio, chat, and desktop sharing for playback. You can see an example of the recording capabilities in 0.81 here: http://goo.gl/p8psx You need to use FireFox or Chrome to view the recording as we us only non-patent encumbered codecs for playback (VP8 and Theora). > You can install bbb on a Ubuntu 10.04 server easily, and you might have problems if you want to install it on a 12.04 Ubuntu server. We recommend you install BigBlueButton 0.81 on Ubuntu 10.04.  We'll support Ubuntu 12.04 in a future version. Thanks Mesut for sharing your experiences about BigBlueButton! Regards,.. Fred -- BigBlueButton Developer

ResponsesInList.Title: BigBlueButton 0.9.0 Released
ResponsesInList.Text: We are pleased to announce the release of BigBlueButton 0.9.0, our twelfth release to date.  BigBlueButton is an open source web conferencing system for on-line learning with deep integration with Moodle. Our goals of this release were to improve the overall quality of audio, give Teachers more control over the recordings, and increase the likelihood that users enter with a functioning microphone. Features in this release include: improved audio using web real-time communication (WebRTC) support in FireFox and Chrome web browsers, teachers can now choose which segments of their class are recorded using the Start/Stop Record button, and users now test their microphone before joining the audio bridge and can also join in Listen Only mode We believe every student with a web browser should have access to a high-quality on-line learning experience. This release is a significant step towards that goal. You’ll find detailed information on this release — including detailed overview, installation instructions (Ubuntu 14.04 64-bit), configuration, development instructions, and a frequently asked questions (FAQ) at our new documentation web site http://docs.bigbluebutton.org/ . The BigBlueButton client is localized in over 30 languages.  This localization effort is done entirely by our community. The BigBlueButtonBN and RecordingsBN Moodle plug-ins (maintained by Blindside Networks) has been downloaded over 100k times in the last 12 months. See: https://moodle.org/plugins/browse.php?list=set&id=2 . For short tutorial videos on using BigBlueButton see http://bigbluebutton.org/videos . We are very proud of this release and wish to thank all the members of the Moodle community who gave us feedback.  We look forward to seeing educational institutions, commercial companies, and the BigBlueButton community at-large build upon this new release to delivery a high-quality on-line learning experience to remote students. For more information on BigBlueButton visit http://bigbluebutton.org/ . Regards,... Fred Dixon BigBlueButton Developer

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BigBlueButton 0.9.0 Released
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Fred for this information. It's nice to see BigBlueButton evolving. Keep up the good work! Séverin

ResponsesInList.Title: Issue with BBB Recordings
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi All, I currently have Moodle 2.85 installation with the latest BBB plugins. I am using Genericconf as the BBB server . When I create an activity for a BBB recording it records the session as I can see this in the Genericconf logs. However when I have created the BBBrecordings resource and click on it there is no recording, it is completely blank. Yet, when I use the Blindside networks test server I can see the recording correctly. I am helping a client out who is on a budget here in Australia. I am only a novice user of Moodle so any hope or pointers of how to get things behaving would be appreciated. Thank you in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Issue with BBB Recordings
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tina, First thing you need to check is if the recording or recordings actually exist in the BigBlueButton server you are trying to connect. If you are running a BBB 0.9, sometimes the users forget to push the recording button (even though the meeting was set to be recorded, the user must push the button to really start recording). Or for any versions, sometimes the recording was not processed for some reason. I would recommend you to do a direct request to the BBB server by using api-mate http://mconf.github.io/api-mate/ (or ask to your system administrator to do so) You can query all the recordings and look for the one you need by title, or if the recordings are too many then you need the internal meeting ID and query for recordings in that specific meetingID. Let us know your findings

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Issue with BBB Recordings
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you Jesus.  I have entered the data into the that link. How do I tell if the recording exist from it please. I am the technical person trying to solve this, I am more a support person than a web support person. Once I can understand the output of the link I can give you that information and we can resolve this issue. I have looked at the Generic Conf and I can see that the meetings have been recorded on their server.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Issue with BBB Recordings
ResponsesInList.Text: Looking at the API Mate. I clicked on getRecordings and it returned code "Success" so I assume that the recording is present on the Generic Conf server given that information. And then when I click on publishRecordings I get "Success" and "True". I hope that is the information you needed from that tool. Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Issue with BBB Recordings
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Tina, Not necessarily. And I am afraid you need to have a good understanding of how the recordings are managed in the BBB server. Are you doing the getRecording request for the specific meeting you are looking for? The BigBluebuttonBN plugin will show you only the recordings related to the BigBlueButtonBN activities in the course it is. If there are recordings in the BBB server from other courses you will see them by using the getRecordings command, but they don't necessarily belong to the course where you have the recordingsBN instance. You need to execute the query for the specific meetingID you are looking for. You can see that ID if you launch into a session from your moodle and while you are in you run a getMeetings command using apimate Take that ID and use it to recover the recordings. If after the recording is made you have recordings in the recordings element, so all is good. NExt thing to look at is the connectivity between your Moodle server and the BBB server The response is always an XML file like this <response><returncode>SUCCESS</returncode><recordings/><messageKey>noRecordings</messageKey><message>There are not recordings for the meetings</message></response> If there is success and no recordings. Well there are just no recordings. If there is success and there are recordings, in the element recordings you should see something like this for each recording in that server: 
```text
<recording>
   <recordID>26961dd06cd95364e5fc58cdb3e69837609b59ee-1414094627549</recordID>
   <meetingID>3c9da89e522728730c41bd16c82624d4-2-1</meetingID>
   <name>BBB Test</name>
   <published>true</published>
   <startTime>1414094627000</startTime>
   <endTime>1414095020000</endTime>
   <
metadata
>
      <originservername>192.168.22.147</originservername>
      <contextactivitydescription>Test</contextactivitydescription>
      <contextactivity>BBB Test</contextactivity>
      <origin>Moodle</origin>
      <recording>true</recording>
      <
context
>English 101</context>
      <originversion>2.7 (Build: 20140512)</originversion>
      <originservercommonname />
      <origintag>moodle-mod_bigbluebuttonbn (2014101002)</origintag>
   </metadata>
   <playback>
      <format>
         <type>presentation</type>
         <url>http://ANYURL/presentation</url>
         <length>7</length>
      </format>
   </playback>
</recording>
```
 
```text

```
 
```text

```
 You are looking for the recording for an specific meetingID that belongs to the activity you created in your moodle <meetingID>3c9da89e522728730c41bd16c82624d4-2-1</meetingID>

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Live Classes in Moodle - open source projects
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I did not realize my question would post so much debate.  I have used blackboard collaborate as a student before and is good tool to do online teaching.  So back to topic I gather that most people tend to use: 1. Blackboard Collaborate (Paid) 2. WizIQ (Paid) 3. bigblubutton. (Open Source) Any other open source projects that teachers use besides these? Regards Terry

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Live Classes in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Terry, I've used Blackboard Collaborate (Elluminate) a fair amount and liked it. Something worth noting: I haven't yet seen a media- server based web conferencing platform that is not paid. Many offer fremium pricing (free for smaller numbers of participants and restricted features/options, e.g. https://www.meetingburner.com/ ) but if you want to use them professionally, you normally have to pay. Case in point, BigBlueButton http://bigbluebutton.org/ software is indeed free and open source so you can download it and install it on your own media server. If you have the expertise and the time to do this and manage it yourself, that's great and you can save yourself some money. However, for most people, this isn't an option so they're looking at a hosting service or commercial support of some kind, i.e. http://bigbluebutton.org/commercial-support/ There's also more options to add to the list: https://moodle.org/plugins/view/mod_openmeetings https://moodle.org/plugins/view/mod_netucate (German) https://moodle.org/plugins/view/mod_videoconsultation https://moodle.org/plugins/view/mod_webinar (Adobe Connect) There may be more, so it's worth checking the Moodle plugins database for webinar service integration modules: https://moodle.org/plugins/index.php I hope this helps!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problem whit Adobe Connect on ISP server
ResponsesInList.Text:
Figured out the problem thanks to Adrian Schlegel With ACP 9.0.4 Adobe introduced the Enhanced Security feature wich is on by default ( http://blogs.adobe.com/connectsupport/using-the-xml-api-with-enhanced-security/ ). For the Plugin to work you need to disable this feature. This works at the moment. According to Adobe they will enforce this in the future: " Make sure to update such integrations with session identifier after
logging in and use secured Web Services APIs so that the integrations
keep working after this option is removed in the near future and
enhanced security is enabled by default." So I guess the plugin will have to be updated to be able to use the secured Web Services APIs. Would be nice to have SSO enabled for Hosted solution like they have for the Webinar Plugin. W

Hi all,

We are starting a project to review/assess Web Conferencing solutions for our institution which may or may not involve a Moodle plug-in in the end. ResponsesInList.Title: restricting user access in folders
ResponsesInList.Text: HI all I want to establish a topic that all designated users  (Students and supervisors) can access but within that topic, I would like individual FOLDERS which contain exam results that only the student, supervsior and manager can see.  Is it possible to have wider access to a topic, but restrict access to folders within the topic?  And to have different user access (Individuals)  for each folder?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: restricting user access in folders
ResponsesInList.Text: You need to investigate groups and groupings. Put your users - students/supervisors/managers into separate groups and then put them each into a grouping . Then allocate one folder to a one grouping/another to another and so on. Not sure if you are using 1.9 or 2.o but here is a videothat explains it and there is also documentation here Groupings

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Elluminate vs. Dimdim vs. WizIQ vs. Adobe Acrobat Connect
ResponsesInList.Text: We have been using Elluminate with Moodle for about two years now. We also are currently in the process of re-evaluating our commitment to the Elluminate platform as we are finding it to be quite expensive. During our review process I spend a fair bit of time demoing solutions from Adobe, WebEx, GoToMeeting, Microsoft and several other companies. We hold fairly large sessions of 40-60 users which doesn't seem to be supported by the 'free' options. Of the solutions that I investigated, I really preferred Adobe Connect Pro. I found it to be very flexible and intuitive. I seemed to be a good fit for the Moodle philosophy as well. I also found a reseller that does a Moodle-Adobe integration. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Elluminate vs. Dimdim vs. WizIQ vs. Adobe Acrobat Connect
ResponsesInList.Text: Try www.rukuku.com — absolutely great teaching tool and LMS. It is now free of charge, but I am not sure if it will remain so for much longer as I cannot imagine such product staying free. The platform has just launched recently, which may explain why it has not gained more popularity. The company is based in Silicon Valley in America, I expect them to gain more popularity soon as Rukuku is so easy to use, and just looks beautiful. I love the name too! I think their web conferencing is amazing, and it is all free, and so is all other functionality. I tried their built-in interactive many-to-many whiteboard (Mediaboard) - it is great for group writing and editing images. They also offer a chat and all teaching materials are organized in a forum called Courseline - separate for each course. I found it convenient because the discussion in the Courseline is structured and focused on particular pieces of content in your course. The company recently announced on their Facebook page that they will offer an iPad application in a few days too. All in all, www.rukuku.com is an amazing (and beautifully designed) alternative to the outdated flash-based Adobe Connect or the clunky WizIQ. It is kind of like a very cool version of Google Hangouts specifically designed for training and education. However, some small functions you would find in Adobe Connect Pro are not there yet, e.g. no raising hands or polls. I could not find screen sharing either. What I loved was their integrated course authoring suite called Composer - it is possible to create courses very quickly, and even sell your courses on the built-in Marketplace. I haven't tried creating a full course yet. There are not so many courses there now, but the number of courses is growing every week. I use rukuku.com for tutoring once a week, and I absolutely love it!

ResponsesInList.Title: BigBlueButton Webinar not completing
ResponsesInList.Text: We are running Moodle 2.6.2+ and BBB server Build 4357-2014-02-06, and BBB plugin 2013110104. It was reported to me this morning that the recordings were not coming up after a short test Webinar, then the actual Webinar. On investigation, I found there were two students who had logged in initially during the test to help with testing, then walked away from the machines and left them logged in. Even with the setting ticked for "Students must wait for moderator to join", the students remaining logged in keeps the webinar going. (And the recording as well) My questions are: Is it possible for a moderator to "kick" a student out of a session? Why would students remain in after the last moderator has left? Kind Regards Peter

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BigBlueButton Webinar not completing
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Peter, My questions are: > Is it possible for a moderator to "kick" a student out of a session? Yes! Any moderator can kick any viewer out of a session.  To kick a viewer, move your mouse over their name in the Users window.  You'll see a row of icons appear next to their name -- click the 'x' icon to kick them out of the session. Once all users have been kicked out (or have logged out) and there are no more active users, the recording of the session will stop and the BigBlueButton server will process the recording to create the playback. If you are going to record your sessions, you may also wish to put a time limit in the sessions.  Make sure you give yourself lots of extra time to account for students how join early.  For example, if you have a three hours class, you may set the maximum duration for the session to 4 hours (320 minutes). This ensures that even if students linger, once the server hits 320 minutes, it will end the session for you. Regards,... Fred -- BigBlueButton Developer

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BigBlueButton Webinar not completing
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Fred, Thanks for the quick reply. Unfortunately, I don't seem to have the icons appear next to the user, only their name (as per the below screenshot) Any ideas why? Kind Regards Peter

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BigBlueButton Webinar not completing
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, There was another question that you didn't answered: "Why would students remain in after the last moderator has left?" Kicking all users before logout, is painful!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BigBlueButton Webinar not completing
ResponsesInList.Text: By design the session runs until the last user left the meeting. The way a moderator can manage to kick all the users at once is to terminate the meeting manually or automatically. And this must be done by using the third part application, in this case Moodle. Manually: When the BigBlueButtonBN activity has been set for opening the session in the same tab, and after the Moderator/Teacher logs out from BBB the user is sent back to Moodle. The page where the user lands shows a list of the BigBlueButtonBN activities for the course with an End button at the end. If you click that button, an end command will be sent to BBB meaning that the meeting is terminated and all the users kicked out. Automatically: You can also set up a duration for the meeting. This feature was included for 0.8x to prevent recordings to last forever when one or more users (typically students) let the session open. If you decide to use this feature be aware that there is no way to change the duration once the meeting has been created, and if the meeting was created (meaning that some one get into the meeting) before the time it was scheduled, the meeting could end before the session was intended to end. To play safe, give the session about 15 minutes before and 15 after the planned time. If the meeting was supposed to be from 10:00 am to 11:00am, give to the duration 90 minutes. So the teacher can join the session 15 minutes before hand and left a little later if needed. Jesus Federico

ResponsesInList.Title: BigBlueButton 0.9.0-beta Released
ResponsesInList.Text: We (the core developers of BigBlueButton) are pleased to announce the availability of BigBlueButton 0.9.0-beta .  Our goals for this release were to give Teachers more control over the recording during the class, to improve the overall quality of audio, and to increase the likelihood that users enter with a functioning microphone. To achieve these goals, we implemented the following major new features: Start/Stop Button for Recording -- Moderators can now mark segments of the class for later playback. Improved Audio -- BigBlueButton now takes advantage of the web real-time communications (WebRTC) framework built into FireFox and Chrome to give users higher quality, lower latency audio. Microphone Check -- BigBlueButton now gives every user a chance to check their microphone before entering the session, ensuring when they enter the session they are ready to participate. Listen Only Mode -- Users without a microphone can join audio in 'Listen Only' mode. In this mode, BigBlueButton displays a speaker icon next to their name letting everyone know they can hear (but not speak). Here are some screen shots of the new Start/Stop button for managing the recording of the session. Here is a screen shot of the new audio chooser. We have three new videos for this release. A video showing how to connect, configure, and test your microphone with BigBlueButton 0.9.0-beta. A video showing how to use BigBlueButton as a student. A video showing how to present a lecture with BigBlueButton and moderate others. We wish to thank the following organizations for their contributions towards this release: Blindside Networks -- Core development, documentation, QA, and release management Seneca College -- Client development Mconf -- Listen Only audio iMDT -- Lock Settings SpeakServe -- Client development HostBBB -- Testing We wish to thank the BigBlueButton Committers for this release: Richard Alam - Lead Architect Felipe Cecagno - Client Fred Dixon - Project Manager Tiago Jacobs - red5 Chad Pilkey - Client Gustavo Salazar - Server We also wish to thank the members of the BigBlueButton community that helped localize this version.  At the time of this post, we have over 95% of the language strings localized for Albanian, Armenian, Bulgarian, Estonian, French, German, Hungarian, Italian, Norwegian, Polish, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, Ukrainian, and Welsh. We have been developing BigBlueButton 0.9.0-beta for almost eleven months.  Our demo server has been running builds of 0.9.0-beta for the past two months.  In addition, our developer community has been using and giving feedback on BigBlueButton 0.9.0-beta for over six weeks.  The core of the product is looking solid. We're now working on finishing the localization, documentation, accessibility , and documentation in preparation for the release of 0.9.0 (it will be our twelfth release). If you are an administrator of a Moodle server looking for a synchronous, web-conferencing system designed for on-line learning, we encourage you to try out BigBlueButton 0.9.0-beta.  You'll find the new WebRTC-based audio a big improvement.  Technically, it's 48 Khz audio encoded in OPUS transmitted in UDP.  From the user's perspective, it just sounds great. The Moodle plugins for BigBlueButton (BigBlueButtonBN and RecordingsBN) have been actively developed and maintained for over four years now.  They have been tested and updated for use with Moodle 2.7.2 (see BigBlueButton Moodle plugins ).   The plugins come pre-configured with a test-server running BigBlueButton 0.9.0-beta so you can try it out right away . In the BigBlueButton project we believe that every student with a web browser should have access to a high quality, on-line learning experience. For more information on this release, see: Detailed Overview - A detailed breakdown of the new major and minor features in BigBlueButton 0.9.0-beta Installation Instructions for Ubuntu 14.04 64-bit -  Step-by-step instructions to install BigBlueButton 0.9.0-beta on Ubuntu 14.04 64-bit Warm Regards,... Fred -- BigBlueButton Developer

ResponsesInList.Title: Server Specs - BigBlueButton
ResponsesInList.Text: Looking for opinions!! I have been running BBB on a server that does not meet even the minimum specs.  (2.0GHz Dual Core, 4GB RAM, 350GB Hard Drive) I ran it for testing purposes, the most I would ever have connect is 20, before I would see the load begin to be too high. The test has been successful, and now I want to go live with a new server.   I know I want to be above the minimum specs I hope to have up to 100 users on at a time.  I hope to find out what others are running their BBB on and how many users are on it Mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Server Specs - BigBlueButton
ResponsesInList.Text: Mike, Per usual with this type of system and deployment - your specific environment and the setups of your students will have a significant impact on how everything performs. Most of the time our server is in use it has between 30-70 concurrent users. We maxed it out at 124 - once. It worked, but I did notice some mildly degraded audio, especially in the recording. Based on monitoring, we believe that was more a function of running into bandwidth limits (on our client side) rather than pushing the server to any sort of limits. We have a fully virtualized infrastructure - for production systems we make sure we slightly under-provision the underlying hardware. Our BBB installation is running with 8 cores (the underlying system is 2.3GH Xeons) and 16GB of RAM. The filesystem is running on a flash-based subsystem.

Once again, thank you. Mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Unable to connect to the BigBlueButton server
ResponsesInList.Text: If you get that error either your Moodle server doesn't have access to the BigBlueButton server or the BigBlueButton server you are using is not working properly (so the response sent to the Moodle server is not correct). You don't need to install your own BigBlueButton server to test it. You can use the default values and create/use meetings as it is shown in the video included in the plugin page https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=mod_bigbluebuttonbn Just keep in mind that your Moodle server needs to be able to communicate with the bigbluebutton server using CURL. The first call the plugin makes is to validate the BBB version parsing the xml response that you usually get from here http://test-install.blindsidenetworks.com/bigbluebutton/api/ Also, as always, the more information you provide (specially versions you are using, settings you have and steps you followed), the easier for anyone to help you out. Regards,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Unable to connect to the BigBlueButton server
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Miki, If the configuration by default works so the plugin and the moodle server configuration are correct. So there are a few things you may want to check: First. By chance, are you missing the protocol in the url? >url setting like this: " 10.0.9.92/bigbluebutton/" It should be http://10.0.9.92/bigbluebutton/ , if that is the url you use to access to your BBB server, which by the way, assuming you have a n standard and complete installation, it should show you the demo page. Also, if you test this URL in your browser http://10.0.9.92/bigbluebutton/api/ do you get the same XMl you got from the test-install server? You should. If you don't so your BBB server is broken. And finally, did you replace the salt (AKA shared secret) by default with the one used by your server? The one that comes by default only works for test-install, at least you replace the salt in your BBB server. By the way, the XML response you got in the browser has nothing to do with the response your Moodle server should get. That only means that your client computer can communicate with the BBB server, but doesn't mean the Moodle server can. JF

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Unable to connect to the BigBlueButton server
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Mike, Thanks for sharing your experience. You can also try restarting the server but you should not really need it for diagnosis. The first thing you want to try is of course to make sure that the target BBB server is working fine using the demo page installed by default. When you are trying to make the plugin to work for the very first time, we recommend testing with the configuration by default. If that works you can discard a bunch of things. If these two conditions are fulfilled, then you can proceed with changing the URL and SALT. Now, if after these three steps you still have problems, the first thing I would check is communication between servers. Making a wget call from the Moodle server to the BBB server can give you a good idea about what can be possible wrong. 
```text
wget -O - 
http://demo.bigbluebutton.org/bigbluebutton/api
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Web Conferencing for Free or Almost Free...
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a small group of students that I conference with so I don't want to pay some host $50 per month.  I find that Adobe Connect, BBB, Elluminate, and OpenMeetings only make sense if you have an expensive server and large bandwidth.  What if you are just meeting with a few students? Join.Me - https://join.me/ - Free - Supported by LogMeIn company.  You install a very small exe on your machine and I've have broadcasted my desktop up to 20 people at the same time. You can allow any of them to control your desktop, it's super easy to chat and send files. Pros: Free Broadcasts desktop up to 20 people with high quality. Can transfer files between host and participants. Participants don't need to install ANY software. Cons: No VOIP - you'll need Skype or something else. No Webcam support Need to install a small piece of software to start. They just need a flash enabled browser. Can't "trade" desktop views. Yvew http://vyew.com/s/ - Shares a whiteboard with everyone. Free up to 10 participantss.  Yvew even has a table explaining why Yvew is better than Adobe Connect and WebEx. ( http://vyew.com/site/product/comparison ) Pros: Free (Up to 10 people) Saves your sessions so that people can go back and review. People can easily share pictures, documents, videos. Can make breakout rooms and subchat rooms. Webcam and Audio Support Many Administrator features.. you can give people moderator access if you want. Can share desktops (not tested) Cons: All clients need a flash browser. Video quality of webcam poor compared to Skype. Audio is not as good as well.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Web Conferencing for Free or Almost Free...
ResponsesInList.Text: Skype - Free PROS: Free Best audio and webcam quality on the internet.  (Better than Big Blue Button, Adobe Connect, illuminate. Works on Linux, OSX, Windows CONS: Students can't drop in on a conference call after it's started. You have to shut down the entire call and recall everyone Desktop sharing is terrible blurry quality. You also can't control their desktop at all or point at items.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Web Conferencing for Free or Almost Free...
ResponsesInList.Text: As one of the developers of CliqMeet ( https://www.cliqmeet.com ) i would like to share this tool. IMHO : Pros: Free for non commercialized usage, deveoped by a german university startup at the TU Munich Mostly HTML5 (Powered by Node.JS and Websockets, Ready for WebRTC as soon most browsers support it) Share PDF-Presentations, Whiteboard, Files, Watch Videos together, Text Editor, etc Webcam and Audio Support, record your sessions, support for mobile devices by Live-Streaming Widget-Based organization of room with layouts Can share desktop with Teamviewer and Java Cons: Beta, english language 90% supported, you will need a modern browser Please tell us! Give it a try, we would love to get some feedback.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Web Conferencing for Free or Almost Free...
ResponsesInList.Text: Another very good option is RHUB. Its web conferencing servers are easy to use and best part is, it has no download of any kind.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BBB Recording Resource error
ResponsesInList.Text: I solved this myself.  I will share in case it happens to someone else. My server is running php handler suphp. ResponsesInList.Title: Is someone inflating the download statistics for AMVONET, WebEx, and OpenMeetings?
ResponsesInList.Text: Is someone (or some organization) inflating the downloads to the web conferencing plugins in the Moodle plugin database to gain a higher ranking? Check out the chart for top 20 downloaded plugins for 2013 ( link ).  Screen shot below. Notice that BigBlueButtonBN checked in at a respectable #13 overall with 52,982 downloads. Nice.  As one of the developers of BigBlueButton, and the co-author of the BigBlueButtonBN and RecordingsBN plugins, it's very satisfying to see our efforts to build an open source web conferencing system benefiting so many in the Moodle community. I've pasted below the chart for top plugin downloads over past 2 months (March 2014 and April 2014). Notice anything odd? The plugins for AMVONET Room, WebEx Meetings, and OpenMeetings -- all web conferencing plugins, and all with impressive download numbers. On the surface, it looks like these three plugins had many thousands of Moodle sites installing them in the last two months. But looking at both charts together, something doesn't look right. Fortunately, moodle.org also tracks the downloads for the past 12 months, which lets us look below the surface to the underlying data and trends for both 2013 and 2014. OpenMeetings Here's a snapshot of the monthly downloads for the past 12 months. Downloads: March 2014: 2,928 April 2014: 16,836 An increase of 575 % AMVONET Again, here are the monthly downloads for the past 12 months. Downloads: March 2014: 142 April 2014: 18,627 An increase of 13,117 % WebEx Source: monthly downloads webex Downloads: March 2014: 124 April 2014: 17,376 An increase of 14,012 %. I'm curious what others think of these numbers? My bet is that someone wanted to inflate the numbers for one of these plugins and, to make the inflated numbers look less obvious, they inflated the numbers of other web conferencing plugins to try and mask the increase. It would be great if someone from MoodleHQ could take a look at the weblogs logs for any unusual download activity. Regards,... Fred -- BigBlueButton Developer

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is someone inflating the download statistics for AMVONET, WebEx, and OpenMeetings?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Fred, as one of the openmeetings moodle plugin c ontributors I totaly agree with you. Normaly I could see in the past arround 2,000 or max. 3,000 downloads of a new om moodle plugin. But in the middle of april the number of downloads increased from one day to another of more than 15,000 per month. At first I looked at the charts of moodle.org like you. Then I thought there could be an article about different web conference systems and how they work with moodle somewhere in the internet. But I could not find any comparison like this. Maybe it was done with a script. I tell you: It was not me . Greetings, Michael

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is someone inflating the download statistics for AMVONET, WebEx, and OpenMeetings?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Michael, Thanks for sharing your thoughts -- inflating download numbers doesn't seem a tactic that would interest an open source developer . Regards,... Fred -- BigBlueButton Developer

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is someone inflating the download statistics for AMVONET, WebEx, and OpenMeetings?

ResponsesInList.Title: BBB - Separate Sessions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi just a quick question. If you install the BBB plugin for Moodle 2.5 and you add the activity into different courses, would these different courses create different sessions in BBB? So if both courses were to go on the system at the same time they wouldn't see eachother on BBB? Many thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BBB - Separate Sessions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Nikki, Yes and yes. All the assumptions are correct. Even if you create two activities in the same course they will create/provide access to different meetings in BigBlueButton. And even more, if you have groups in a course and you set up the activity to use the groups. A different meeting will be created for each group so the students will join the meeting that corresponds to them even though they click on the same link. Teachers have the ability to select what session group are they joining to. Regards, Jesus Federico

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BBB - Separate Sessions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jesus, That's great thank you for your help. Many thanks, Nikki

However MoodleRooms Tech Support states that "you can either host it yourself or subscribe to another Adobe Connect hosting service.", giving us the impression that the MoodleRooms plugin will work with any environment that Adobe Connect is hosted in, including "Adobe hosted Connect" as mentioned in http://www.adobe.com/products/adobeconnect/buying-guide.html . We can not afford to make a $40k investment in an on-premise hosted version, but we can do an Adobe hosted Connect. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PLEASE HELP: Adobe Hosted Connect in MoodleRooms??
ResponsesInList.Text: Pedram, To start the plugin you refer to as the Moodlerooms Adobe connect plugin is not the name of the plugin the Moodle  community would understand. If you are looking for community feedback you are asking about the Adobe Connect community plugin found at https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=mod_adobeconnect . This is the plugin Moodlerooms has reviewed and is available for clients to enable. Historically this plugin will work with hosted adobe connect sites except for the single sign on. This plugin focuses on adobe connect pro, which is an on premise solution, and this is historically the only server type that the plugin supports single sign on for.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle With best web conference solution
ResponsesInList.Text: We've been playing around with various webinar options for several years, going back to the heyday of DimDim when it seemed like it might actually be an opensource alternative to Adobe. After several years and various solutions we're waiting for BigBlueButton to reach 0.8. I really believe that BigBlueButton is the best cost effective solution. If you have the money and infrastructure for an on-site version of Adobe Connect then I hear the integrations with Moodle are pretty good, but it's not a good solution if you don't have a dedicated installation of Connect under the control of the same group that runs your LMS. BigBlueButton meets almost all of our needs right now, but for us to really commit to it we need recording and playback, which should drop in the next few weeks. At that point we'll re-evaluate moving completely over to an integrated installation of BigBlueButton. Right now we make due with a mix of a few other solutions and upload the recordings after the fact to our instance of Kaltura CE.

Our preference is for an integrated solution and we hope that the release of BigBlueButton 0.8 will make that possible, but I'm not sure since 0.8 hasn't been released yet.

ResponsesInList.Title: Audio enabled breakout rooms Re: Moodle With best web conference solution
ResponsesInList.Text: We use Blackboard Collaborate Web Conferencing (formerly "Elluminate Live!", a solution with audio enabled breakout rooms. I did not contribute earlier, because our classroom solution is not open-source. After Blackboard acquired Elluminate some years ago, the famous Moodle bridge plugin disappeared from Moodle Docs Plugin directory. The Elluminate trainer community did wait in vain, how Blackboard, (who is vendor of a commercial LMS also) will handle Elluminate´s Moodle connectivity in the future. Here are the good news: Blackboard did continue to integrate the famous Elluminate engine, now named "Collaborate Web Conferencing" with many LMS (especially all those supporting the LTI standard). Collaborate´s user interface is improved from Elluminate´s plane cockpit GUI, The Java -based engine is still the same and does include audio-enabled breakout-rooms as usual However, recording and playback of actions happening in several breakout rooms might be difficult to handle, several independant audio streams in parallel. It might be a better idea to define several rooms and let participant change the room for group work. This enables you to record each room independantly. Collaborate has a flatrate-like license model limiting the number of seats, but not number of rooms driven in parallel. The dedicated Collaborate-Moodle Integation is currently certified for Moodle up to 2.5x . I´m driving the Collaborate plugin v3.1 on my Moodle 2.6 - without glitches up to now. Please note, that Collaborate´s Moodle plugin is distributed by vendor only and therefore not listed in the Moodle Docs plugin directory. I currently consider this as a conceptual bug of the Moodle Docs site disallowing any documentation about plugins not being distributed there.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DimDim or Elluminate?
ResponsesInList.Text: I have just started looking into web conferencing. I have used elluminate. It's expensive but it works. I am interested in trying out the BigBlueButton . ( http://bigbluebutton.org/ ) It looks like it has most of the functions that I would need. I never really liked the record features of elluminate simply because I never really wanted to watch long meetings again. However, If you invest $299 in Camtasia studio ( http://www.techsmith.com/camtasia/ ), you can record meetings and then cut out the fluff later. There are some free alternative desktop recording options, but Camtasia is, by far, the best out there. I actually use Camtasia a lot to create training videos and lectures. It would be nice if a web-conferencing programs also allowed the recording and editing features that you find in Camtasia. I have also used Camtasia to record someone else's elluminate meeting. It was a good thing since they forgot to hit record at first and then later realized their voice wasn't being recorded. As of this reply, BigBlueButton was still working out some kinks on their whiteboard feature. However, a good, free whiteboard application/website is scribblar.com . ( http://www.scribblar.com/ ) It allows you to create multiple rooms and each room allows multiple pages. It even allows file sharing and pdf uploads of 5 pages. I have used scribblar for lecture rooms in moodle as well as tutoring rooms. I love the fact that you just have to put a link to the room in the moodle course for others to access the whiteboard. It also allows you to lock the room so that others cannot change or delete things if you have a lesson set up or something. It doesn't have a record feature, but again you can use Camtasia to record a session and post it to YouTube or something later. So, my recommendation would be to use 3 programs: BigBlueButton - although I have only seen demos at this point (But it does have a moodle module.) Scribblar - Easy, powerful, and free whiteboard Camtasia - $299, but well worth the money. You will thank yourself for buying a copy.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DimDim or Elluminate?

I'd suggest that it's important to have the range of features that people want, but keep the possiblility of switching off features that administrators don't want to provide, as some features won't be appropriate for some student groups. If it's good enough, it would eventually get drawn into the mainstream Moodle. CamStudio is also open source and it might be possible to integrate it to add features. thanks for the advice. I supose it was a pluggin problem. It was a salt problem. I will try to use the same salt (in a clean install) then i use the: bbb-conf --salt 12345ee... command, . In my case it don't change the salt in: 
```text
/var/lib/tomcat6/webapps/bigbluebutton/demo/bbb_api_conf.jsp
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DimDim or Elluminate? BBB 0.71

Did you use "sudo bbb-conf ...." or execute it as root and not as firstuser user ?
I did the same mistake twice...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DimDim or Elluminate? BBB 0.71
ResponsesInList.Text: @Alan incase you have not sorted this out; yes you are right that bbb-config --saltset <salt> does change the demo api but note that the salt at /var/lib/tomcat6/webapps/bigbluebutton/demo/bbb_api_conf.jsp is for the demo page, if that did not change, then it should not affect you moodle api, it will only affect your demo page. You need to verify that the salt at "cat /var/lib/tomcat6/webapps/bigbluebutton/WEB-INF/classes/bigbluebutton.properties" is the same as that of your moodle API. cheers

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DimDim or Elluminate?
ResponsesInList.Text: The marketing policy of DimDim has not been open at all. They initially talked a lot about open source nature. Then they started delaying the open source releases and got into open source crippleware (no recording feature for example in open source). Now, the delay in open source update is simply too much. In fact, DimDim has most likely used the free word of mouth publicity associated with open source product as a stepping stone. Every company has to make money, but if they could be open right from the beginning about their policy, it would have helped. If one was interested in open source only, one would possibly not have wasted time on DimDim. Having said that, DimDim product looks okay to me for basic web conferencing and scores on ease of use. But, the free version gradually is being marginalised and if you use the free version, you notice how much shout is there about upgrade.

ResponsesInList.Title: BigBlueButton 0.81-RC released
ResponsesInList.Text: We are pleased to announce the availability of a release candidate (RC) for BigBlueButton 0.81 , our eleventh release to date. A release candidate for BigBlueButton means all development is finished, all testing is done, and the only remaining task is to change the label from 0.81-RC to 0.81. Our goal for each release of BigBlueButton is to advance the project in stability, usability , and core features.  A release candidate is the final stage of our development process. Want to give a BIG THANKS to everyone who used an earlier version of 0.81, given us feedback, submitted a bug request, sent us a pull request, or posted or tweeted about our project. For more information, and links to download /upgrade, see release notes . Regards,... Fred -- BigBlueButton Developer

ResponsesInList.Title: Connect-to-Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Folks, I'm up-to-date with the discussion about the Remote Learner Adobe Connect plugin for moodle here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=145225 , particularly in regard to the inability to connect to a hosted adobe solution with SSO. I've just noticed on the adobe site another plugin for use with adobe connect and moodle: http://www.adobe.com/uk/products/adobeconnect/feature-details/connect-moodle.html Does anyone have any experience with this mod? http://www.refineddata.com/learning-management/c2m I can't see any reviews for it, or any mentions of it in moodle.org forums. What is of interest is the money-line: Connect-to-Moodle provides a Single Sign On (SSO) environment in which information passes effortlessly in both directions between the two platforms so users cannot tell where Moodle ends and Adobe Connect begins. The SSO associated with the free integrator doesn't work with Adobe Hosted Solutions (majority of Adobe deployments). I wonder how they have achieved this with: " Connect-to-Moodle is installed as a series of simple drop-in modules, blocks and activities . ", when the discussion on the remote leaner plugin points to adobe being the problem for SSO on hosted solutions? Has anyone had any experience with this mod? Would anyone from Remote Learner like to comment? Cheers, -David

ResponsesInList.Title: BigBlueButton 0.81-beta-2 released
ResponsesInList.Text: We (the core developers of BigBlueButton) are pleased announce the availability of BigBlueButton 0.81-beta-2. BigBlueButton is an open source web conferencing system for on-line learning.  The goal of the project is to provide remote students a high-quality learning experience. We expect to have a release candidate for 0.81 shortly, followed by a final release.  Most of the work now is on finishing the localization strings. We invite you to try out 0.81-beta-2.  Here's what's new in this release: Simplified Interface – BigBlueButton now has a consolidated Users window for easier session management and a more consistent user interface (including updated skin and icons) to help new users get started quickly. Layout Manager – BigBlueButton now enables users to choose from a number of preset layouts to quickly adapt to different modes of learning. Recording – BigBlueButton now records for playback all during a session (including desktop sharing). Text tool for Whiteboard – Presenters can now annotate their slides with text. New APIs – The BigBlueButton API now includes the ability to dynamically configure each client on a per-user bases, thus enabling developers to configure the skin, layout, modules, etc. for each user. There is also a JavaScript interface to control the client. Accessibility – BigBlueButton now supports screen readers JAWS (version 11+) and NVDA. A list of keyboard shortcuts have been added to make it easier to navigate through the interface using the keyboard. LTI Support – BigBlueButton is IMS Learning Tools Interoperability (LTI) 1.0 compliant. This means any LTI consumer can integrate with BigBlueButton without requiring custom plug-ins. Mozilla Persona – The API demos now include examples of how to sign into a BigBlueButton session using Mozilla Persona. Support for LibreOffice 4.0 – BigBlueButton now uses LibreOffice 4.0 for conversion of of MS Office documents ( upload of PDF is still recommend to provide best results). This release has been in development/testing for over thirteen months.  In particular, we've done a lot of work to further simplify the interface. For videos that demonstrate how to use BigBlueButton as a moderator/presenter and as a viewer, see http://www.bigbluebutton.org/videos/ We know that archiving is important to many teachers.  For a sample BigBlueButton recording, click the link below (use FireFox or Chrome to view) http://goo.gl/A0IOXr For integrating BigBlueButton with Moodle, see https://moodle.org/plugins/browse.php?list=set&id=2 For more information on this release, including instructions on how to install (or upgrade from the previous release), see the release notes https://code.google.com/p/bigbluebutton/wiki/ReleaseNotes and visit our project web site http://bigbluebutton.org/ We've been working on BigBlueButton now for over four years.  When the final version this release ships, it will mark the eleventh release of the product. Our goal is to provide remote students a high-quality on-line learning experience.  If you are a teacher and want to provide your students with a synchronous learning environment, then we are building BigBlueButton for you. Regards,... Fred -- BigBlueButton Developer

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: which video conferencing?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sarah We have BigBlueButton integrated with our Moodle LMS and it works great. The moodle plugin for Bigbluebutton allows to join the meeting with a single click. Its integrated with the Moodle calendar so you may schedule your sessions within Moodle and also associate your student groups who can join those meeetings. You can also choose to record these meetings. There is also a BBB Recording module for Moodle which allows publishing of meetings recorded via BBB and they automatically appear in the recording activity. If you arent sure about setting up a BBB server, you may try using a Virtual machine to get started. You may need to configure and open ports to the VM if accessing it from the Internet. Let me know if you need any help with this. Ill try! regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio, Video or web conferencing within Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Our organization has been looking and looking and tried all kings of stuff. Shareware, freeware, commercial software, open source... I think that what is truly needed for this Open Source Learning Management System is a free and Open Source web conferencing tool that can work on various platforms and with no need to install client side stuff . The companies that develop such tools can use the model of Red Hat, Apache and Moodle, and can do well financially by offering fee for service support, hosting, customization, enhancements and training. This is kind of the model of DimDim. DimDim appears like a very promising application and a lot of people have been kind of holding their breath waiting for a stable version to come. So far, we have seen a lot of delays, and I must say I am getting a little skeptical... after all the hype. Also, the product is kind of disappointing from a cross-platform support point of view, and due to the fact that it seems to crash less on windows platforms and browsers versus open source OS and browsers such as Linux and Mozilla (based on our own test). Unfortunately, and because of the frequent crashed, at this point, we had to decide to remove DimDim from our production servers and to hide the items that would have allowed students to use it for current courses. At this point, there seems to be one application with very little marketing by a lot of features to offer. As I was searching over the last couple of years, I kept running into it and kind of discounted it because of all the noise with other up and coming apps. I think that this community aught to give a more serious look at WebHuddle . Unlike many commercial and proprietary apps, and just like DimDim, WebHuddle does not require installation of client side plug-ins. It supports session recording (both screencast and audiocast). For the audio, I understand that one may have to use it with other VoIP tools ( http://www.voip-info.org/wiki-Open+Source+VOIP+Software , Skype, SIPPhone or any other other). Hopefully, some work can be done soon on the audio side. If giants like Google use WebHuddle for Webcast, that says something about the credibility of WebHuddle http://webhuddle.sourceforge.net/demos/32/file_playback.html So my recommendation and support for any tools that integrates and complements Moodle is to look for free OpenSource, multi-platforms web conferencing tools that do not require installation of browser plug ins (this limits a lot the need for support and troubleshooting of students computers). And in the category, I have not seen much that is currently been offered and active besides DimDim (still in Alpha) and WebHuddle (has been in Beta for a while). Once again, while there is a lot of marketing efforts with DimDim (just looks at all the (sometimes redundant) post from the company on this forum), we should not ignore alternatives such as WebHuddle, even if they may be weak in marketing, and possibly (and momentarily) on the audio and for lack of instant integration with Moodle. There are ways to work around these two issues. In regard to Moodle integration, until somebody comes up with an activity plug-in, it is not difficult to just create an HTML link for students and teachers to start a conference. If anybody has feedback on what I just wrote, I would be very glad to hear about it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio, Video or web conferencing within Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Frederic, Four products come to my mind in open source conferencing: DimDim has announced that it is now in beta with the new website look. However, I have not experienced any difference in the things of my specific interest like whiteboard at www1.dimdim.com and at www2.dimdim.com as on date. Webhuddle audio is too bad for me (using webhuddle's own hosting) but I am encouraged by looking at the audio quality of the recorded meeting whose URL you have provided. If there is work around for the audio issue then it would be useful. One more issue with webhuddle is its whiteboard. It has to improve my miles. But, application sharing can be a work around for that at the moment. The most promising open source solution I find for virtual classroom is NEW . I find it feature rich. It can suit dedicated server installations and hosted solution does not appear to be available at the moment. Vmukti (formerly called 1videoconference) is also making some inroads. Its test has not worked for me till now so I cannot say too much about it. Vmukti name may sound strange to many here. Mukti means freedom in Hindi & Sanskrit.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio, Video or web conferencing within Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for your feedback Manish. I am happy to see that DimDim has moved to beta. Last time I had checked (only appears to be a few days), it was still in Alpha. We had extensively tried the Network Education Ware (NEW) system a while back and had great hopes that it would be a solution for us. Unfortunately, we found the system very difficult to setup on our dedicated server and way to complicated. The engineering behind the product may be great, but we found the user interface to be quite rough, the setup and user documentation confusing. In the end, after having to hire VoiP/Linux experts, we got it to work, but the end result was iffy. I would love to learn if others have had a different experience with NEW, or if people have found ways to get DimDim to actually work with actual live classrooms. Also, that vmuki product you mentioned looks great, and it would be nice to know from academic institutions that some people have actually had success using it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio, Video or web conferencing within Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: BigBlueButton is quite nice and it does indeed work easily with a quick installation time. However, at this time I can only install it using a direct connection to the Internet and a dedicated web-facing IP address. I can not install it on a LAN that already has Apache web servers, as BigBlueButton only works reliably with port 80 and the listening port can not be changed (due to the number of servers within the BBB platform). Since Moodle (and many other servers) on my LAN also use port 80 (with Apache), the conflicts are unavoidable unless BigBlueButton is outside the LAN, i.e. on its own Internet IP address, so that it does not have to share port 80. The Moodle plugin (by Dualcode) merely transfers users/privileges information to BigBlueButton and does not help resolve this intrinsic difficulty. BBB is due for the Google Summer of Code this year; hopefully it will emerge as a more flexible platform afterwards, with a few more kinks worked out.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio, Video or web conferencing within Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Nevermind. BigBlueButton does now have a method for changing its default Nginx (and other related) listening ports: bbb-conf --setip bigbluebutton.mydomain.org:81 By doing this and then editing the listening port in the Nginx virtual host file (at /etc/nginx/sites-available/bigbluebutyon) to listen 81; then BigBlueButton will work on port 81. for the most part this seems to be working ok.

ResponsesInList.Title: BBB - Multiple meetings / scheduled mettings
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a client who uses continuous enrolment and needs to run meetings as a "days after enrolment" type schedule. They have worked out a complex system of dates for when different levels of enrolment would be available for the next virtual meeting. Think of it like this: Day 1 : User 1,2 & 3 enrol Day 25: User 4 & 5 enrol Day 30 : Users 1, 2 & 3 do their first scheduled meeting over BBB, share files, do video conferences, that stuff. (Not recorded or assessed) Day 45: More users enrol Day 55 : Users 4 & 5 do their first scheduled meeting Day 60 : Users 1, 2 & 3 have their second scheduled meeting, which is recorded and assessed. etc ... We don't know the calendar dates of "day N", except by counting them out. Days after enrolment type scheduling is a pain, but that's the job. Our second problem is that BBB seems to have a "single activity = single meeting" association. So over time, the course is going to have a stack of use-once-then-discard activities , which is something I'd like to avoid. I'd like to know if there's a way to modify the plugin for moodle (or if there is an existing plugin) that allows multiple schedules for a single activity.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: New version of BigBlueButtonBN plugin for Moodle 1.9 supports record and playback
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi DeWayne, Let's dig a bit deeper ... > It is on a Ubuntu 9.04 os. it runs prfectly when accessed by the local address. I presume you mean Ubuntu 10.04 (that's the only version that we test with the packaging of 0.80). Is your Moodle server located on the same network as your BigBlueButton server?  Specifically, can your Moodle server access your BigBlueButton server via HTTP requests. The BigBlueButtonBN plugin must make direct API calls (via HTTP requests) to the BigBlueButton 0.80 server to create rooms, get recordings, etc. For a BigBlueButton server on a local network (behind a firewall), when you access it with your browser (also running on a computer behind the firewall) everything works.  However, if your Moodle server is located outside your network-- outside your firewall -- such as on a shared hosting site the external Moodle server can't reach in through your firewall to access your BigBlueButton server.  The firewall is doing its job. Let us know the networking setup of your BigBlueButton server and Moodle server and we'll dig a bit deeper. Regards,... Fred -- BigBlueButton Developer

ResponsesInList.Title: Disable camera/audio pop up box
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, When BBB is started it pops up a flash box, asking if camera/audio sharing is allowd, and if the user wants to join the audio session, is it possible I disable this box and just allow camera/audio by default. Thanks, Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Disable camera/audio pop up box
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Paul, It is not possible to disable this security dialog. There is no one-way only audio in BigBlueButton.  When a user joins the audio session, the BigBlueButton client creates a two-way audio bridge. The moderator can set all users to join muted, but the underlying audio channel is still two-way, hence the need for the security dialog to request the user's permission for access to webcam and microphone. Regards,... Fred -- BigBlueButton Developer

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Big Blue Button on Shared Server
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Yusuf, The role of the user when entering BigBlueButton (moderator or viewer) depends on the user's role in Moodle. If they are a student, they will enter the BigBlueButton session as viewer. If they have any other privliges in Moodle beyond student, they will enter BigBlueButton as a moderator. Your probably testing the plugin when logged into your Moodle site as administrator, which is why you are always entering the BigBlueButton session as moderator. Try logging into your Moodle site as a student and enter the BigBlueButton session.  You should join as a viewer. Regards,... Fred -- BigBlueButton Developer

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodleand Big Blue Button on different servers
ResponsesInList.Text: I am trying to integrate Big Blue Button with Moodle, the BBB readme file says that Moodle & Big Blue Button need to be on different servers? Is there any reason for this requirement? Thanks, Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodleand Big Blue Button on different servers
ResponsesInList.Text: We recommend two different servers mainly due performance but also because it makes easier the administration. Off course if you have a big server and only few users, you could handle the two services in the same box. Just keep in mind that out of the box BigBlueButton has a web server (nginx) configured to listen the port 80 (as any other web server has by default). You can deal with the configuration of moodle on nginx or if you want to install a different webserver like apache, you would need to put either of them to listen to a different por, hence to do extra configuration. We as BigBlueButton developers and commercial providers never do that, not even for development, but yes, we have learn of several deployments of both services in one box. So, the use of two servers is highly recommended but it's not mandatorily required. Regards Jesus Federico

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodleand Big Blue Button on different servers
ResponsesInList.Text: Good reply Jesus. Paul, see also this FAQ entry: http://code.google.com/p/bigbluebutton/wiki/FAQ#We_recommend_running_BigBlueButton_on_port_80 Regards,... Fred -- BigBlueButton Developer

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodleand Big Blue Button on different servers

ResponsesInList.Title: BBB Attendance Report in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Reporting "attendance" is one of the selection requirements for a webconferencing software. How is the specific Moodle-initiated BBB session identified to the BBB server ? Is is accessed via a get URL ? If so, to get the start and end time of a participant, two details could be added to that URL : an "entry url" and an "exit url". When the BBB server does a successful get on the entry url, it sends "time of entry" to the mdl_bigbluebuttonbn_log table. When the user exits the session (e.g., via logging out or losing the connection for whatever reason) the BBB server does a get on the exit url and sends the "time of exit" to the mdl_bigbluebuttonbn_log table. Does that make sense?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BBB Attendance Report in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text:
Yes, that is the only implementation that could be done by now, but anyway the report would not be 100% reliable.

The exceptions for the use case you are proposing are when the users close the tab or browser, or when the communication fails and the user get disconnected.

There is no problem with joining time, but with the leaving time.

Regards,

Jesus Federico
